source_file: Hirakawa et al. - 2025 - Diffuse Pulmonary Meningotheliomatosis Presenting with the Cheerios Sign Diagnosed by a Transbronchi.pdf

evidence.exact_quote: A 48-year-old woman with Turner syndrome presented with diffuse pulmonary nodules exhibiting the Cheerios sign.
A 48-year-old non-smoking woman presented with an abnormal shadow on chest radiography during routine health screening.
A 48-year-old non-smoking woman presented with an abnormal shadow on chest radiography during routine health screening.
Although the patient had few symptoms, she visited a local hospital because of the results of the routine health screening.

TBLC was performed using a 1.9 mm cryoprobe with a 6second freezing time and the blood-blocking balloon technique. One sample was obtained from each of the right B 8b and B 9 segments where the Cheerios sign was clearly observed.

evidence.extracted_value: Diffuse centrilobular granular opacities and nodular shadows in both lungs, with some nodules having central lucency with a surrounding thin wall (Cheerios sign)
evidence.exact_quote: CT of the chest showing diffuse centrilobular granular opacities and nodular shadows in both lungs. Some nodules had central lucency with a surrounding thin wall, consistent with the 'Cheerios sign'.

evidence.extracted_value: Multiple small nodules measuring approximately 2 mm in diameter in the interstitium, consisting of low-grade, round to short spindle-shaped cells resembling meningeal epithelial cells, with uniform round nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm. No cellular atypia, necrosis, or significant inflammation observed.
evidence.exact_quote: Histopathological examinations of both specimens revealed multiple small nodules measuring approximately 2 mm in diameter in the interstitium. The nodules consisted of low-grade, round to short spindle-shaped cells resembling meningeal epithelial cells, with uniform round nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm. No cellular atypia, necrosis, or significant inflammation was observed.

evidence.extracted_value: Positive for epithelial membrane antigen (EMA), progesterone receptor (PgR), and CD56
evidence.exact_quote: Immunohistochemically, these cells were positive for the epithelial membrane antigen (EMA), progesterone receptor (PgR), and CD 56

evidence.extracted_value: Discontinuation of estrogen and progesterone hormone therapy
evidence.exact_quote: Estrogen and progesterone hormone therapy were discontinued, and the disease remained stable without treatment.

evidence.extracted_value: Stable disease without progression over 7-month follow-up
evidence.exact_quote: No further disease progression was observed over a follow-up period of seven months without treatment.

The patient had a history of Turner syndrome and had been receiving hormone supplementation with estrogen and progesterone since childhood. At the time of the DPM diagnosis, the patient was diagnosed with a uterine polyp.
